title: Case Study: Thumb Arthritis in a 55-Year-Old Administrative Assistant
clinical_history: A 55-year-old right-handed administrative assistant presented with a 6-month history of progressive pain and stiffness in her right thumb. The patient reported that the pain started insidiously, with no specific incident or trauma. She described the pain as being worst in the morning and improving throughout the day, but with increasing stiffness and pain over the past few months. The patient reported difficulty with activities such as turning door handles, opening jars, and using her computer mouse.
aggrevating_factors: Activities that involve gripping, twisting, or turning, such as opening jars, turning door handles, or using a screwdriver. Prolonged computer use also exacerbates her symptoms.
picture: The patient exhibits tenderness and swelling over the first metacarpal joint and thumb, with reduced range of motion and crepitus on movement.
easing_factors: Rest, ice application, and over-the-counter pain relievers provide temporary relief.
past_history: The patient has a history of mild osteoarthritis in her knees and hands, but has not required any surgical interventions.
medical_history: Hypertension, controlled with medication. No history of inflammatory arthritis or other rheumatic conditions.
medications: Acetaminophen 1000mg as needed for pain, up to 3 times a day.
personal_history: Married with two adult children. Works full-time as an administrative assistant. Enjoys gardening and cooking in her free time.
imaging: X-rays of the right thumb and wrist show joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation at the first carpometacarpal joint, consistent with thumb osteoarthritis.
